Health: Reviews
(Question No. 1474)
Mr Alexander asked the Minister for Health, in writing, on 21 March 2013:

During the (a) Anticoagulation Review, (b) Statins Review, (c) Anti Dementia Review, and (d) Diabetes Review, did the original terms of reference or deadlines for submission change; if so, (i) how were stakeholders notified of the changes, and (ii) what consultation was undertaken.
Ms Plibersek: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(a) Anticoagulation Review
The Terms of Reference did not change once the Review commenced.

The deadline for public submissions did change. The original deadline for the open public submission stage was 21 February 2013. Following representations by two of the key stakeholders that more time was required to finalise their input for the review, the deadline was extended by 48 hours to close on 23 February 2012.
(i) The extension was broadcast in a Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) website update, and by direct email to the stakeholders who requested the extension.

(ii) A full public consultation was undertaken. Additionally, individual sponsor companies had the opportunity to meet with the Reviewer and the Department of Health and Ageing, and were also provided several opportunities to comment throughout the review. An open stakeholder forum was also held.
(b) Statins Review
The Terms of Reference did not change once the Review commenced.
(i) The deadline for submissions by sponsors was changed following a request by sponsors. Sponsors were notified by a letter from my Department.

(ii) On 2 December 2011, my Department provided relevant companies with a copy of the preliminary Report of the Statins Review. In light of the size and complexity of the preliminary Report, the consultation period in relation to the preliminary Report was extended from 16 December 2011 to 1 March 2012.
An information session for affected sponsors was held on 8 December 2011.

As per usual practice, the report for the Statins Review was sent to the affected sponsors in May 2012. The report was considered by the sub-committees of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) (Drug Utilisation Sub-Committee (DUSC) and Economics Sub-Committee (ESC)) in June 2012. It was then provided to the companies for comment prior to consideration by the PBAC in July 2012 with the recommendations of the PBAC provided to Government thereafter. The report was not made public, but a public summary document agreed between sponsors and PBAC is available, as per usual practice, on the PBS website at http://www.pbs.gov.au/info/industry/listing/elements/pbac-meetings/psd
(c) Anti-Dementia Review
The Terms of Reference did not change once the Review commenced. The deadlines for submissions did not change.
(d) Diabetes Review
The Terms of Reference have not changed since the Review commenced.

The deadline for public submissions did change. The original deadline for the open public submission stage for Phase 1 (Blood glucose test strips) was extended by two weeks, following a request by key stakeholders. The deadline for the open public submission stage for Phase 2 (insulin pumps) was not extended. However a longer period was allowed due to the Christmas break. Stakeholders had a total of eight weeks to provide a submission for Phase 2.
(i) Stakeholders were notified of the submission deadlines via email and the deadlines were provided on the PBS website.

(ii) A full public consultation was undertaken for Phases 1 and 2 of this review. An open stakeholder forum was also held for Phase 1. Sponsors have been and continue to be provided several opportunities to comment throughout the review.
Health: Reviews
(Question No. 1477)
Mr Alexander asked the Minister for Health, in writing, on 21 March 2013:

During the (a) Anticoagulation Review, (b) Statins Review, (c) Anti Dementia Review, and (d) Diabetes Review, (i) what data has been solicited from sponsor companies, (ii) how long were sponsor companies given to provide this data, and (iii) how does this timeframe compare with the time taken by the Pharmaceutical Benefit Advisory Committee to evaluate a submission for listing a new medicine on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
Ms Plibersek: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) process is a 17 week cycle from receipt of submission, to PBAC consideration. To date post-market reviews have taken anywhere between seven to 12 months, including multiple periods of public consultation.

Submissions for new or extended listings on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme are initiated by sponsors, not by the PBAC or the Department of Health and Ageing. Major submissions must be submitted 17 weeks prior to the PBAC meeting, with companies provided one week to provide additional information or comment in response to the Drug Utilisation Sub-Committee (DuSC) and Economic Sub-Committee (ESC) processes, before provision to the PBAC for final consideration.
In respect to post-market reviews, it is a matter for individual sponsors as to the data they provide in their submissions to a review.

Post-market reviews to date have followed a process of initial public call for submissions of between six and nine weeks depending on the time of year. Additionally, all reviews have provided for a period of subsequent comment on the draft report, for a period of between two and six weeks, again depending on the time of year.
